item.title: Valve‚Äôs Steam Machine Could Cost More Than A PS5 Pro
item.content:encoded:
The Steam Machine marks Valve‚Äôs long-awaited return to the console wars. It looks slick and sounds powerful enough to play modern games on decent settings. But Valve is leaving the biggest question of all unanswered: how much will it cost? There‚Äôs no official price tag yet, though we do have some early clues that point to the Steam Machine being at least $800 or more.

Valve probably wants to wait until closer to launch before committing to a price tag for both the 512GB and 2TB models. It wouldn‚Äôt want a repeat of what happened to the Nintendo Switch 2 when President Trump torpedoed the Mario maker‚Äôs initial pre-order plans by announcing massive tariffs days before they were set to begin. Valve is promising to reveal more information in early 2026. But that doesn‚Äôt mean we‚Äôre completely in the dark about how much the Steam Machine will cost.

‚ÄúSteam Machine‚Äôs pricing is comparable to a PC with similar specs,‚Äù Valve told The Verge when it asked it if would cost more than PS5 Pro. Designer Pierre-Loup Griffais elaborated a bit more. ‚ÄúWe intend for it to be positioned closer to the entry level of the PC space, but to be very competitive with a PC you could build yourself from parts,‚Äù he said.

Based on The Verge‚Äòs napkin math, building a PC from off-the-shelf parts to match the Steam Machine‚Äôs specs would start at around $800, but it wouldn‚Äôt get you anywhere close to the living room device‚Äôs small, compact footprint. That would require spending closer to $1,000, before taking into account things like storage. The PS5 Pro starts at $750 and comes with 2TB of storage, but it‚Äôs also benefitting from a massive supply chain operation from a company that‚Äôs been mass-manufacturing home consoles for decades.

Still, it sounds like Valve doesn‚Äôt just want the Steam Machine to cater to existing PC gamers who are used to investing $1,500 and beyond in new rigs. Affordability also sounds like a top priority and there‚Äôs always the question of how much of the upfront cost of the hardware Valve is willing to eat on its end. A bigger Steam install base ultimately means more people paying Valve a 30-percent commission on every game they buy.

‚ÄúBut we obviously also wanted to make the device affordable,‚Äù Valve engineer Yazan Aldehayyat told IGN ‚ÄúWe understand that affordability is really important, so we kept that in mind and made sure that‚Äôs a device that‚Äôs going to be reachable for a lot of people.‚Äù

He continued, ‚ÄúThe affordability piece you mentioned is one of the reasons why we think a Steam Machine makes a lot of sense right now. So it‚Äôs just something that we thought about every time we made a hardware decision, a feature decision, is to make sure that we keep it as approachable, as affordable as possible.‚Äù

Whether Valve can keep the Steam Machine pricing ‚Äúconsole-level‚Äù will ultimately determine whether it ends up feeling like a pricey PC accessory like the ROG Xbox Ally X or a real competitor in the broader console gaming space. It could also be a bellwether indicating if the next-gen Xbox and PlayStation 6 stay in the realm of $500-$600 or start pushing the barrier to entry even higher.

item.title: The Internet Reacts To Valve‚Äôs New Steam Machine
item.content:encoded:
In a world where video game consoles are largely becoming PCs for your TV, it makes sense that Valve would be jumping back into the console market with a new Steam Machine. The original Steam Machine launched in 2015 and let you play your PC games on your TV, but the project was short-lived. Valve stopped selling the thing in 2018, but hasn‚Äôt stopped trying to bring PC gaming and the SteamOS to new formats. Just take a look at the Steam Deck. Now, the Steam Machine is back with a new model for a new era. Will the public be more receptive this time around?

We don‚Äôt have a price or release date for the new Steam Machine just yet beyond a 2026 window, and the cost will likely color how folks react to the device overall. We do know that the cube-like computer is around six times more powerful than the Steam Deck is. The six-inch tall box has a sleek, lowkey design that the PlayStation 5‚Äôs Seto-Kaiba-ass popped collar could learn from, and its controller has traditional analog sticks on top of the signature trackpad that made the original‚Äôs controller an oddity. It also doubles as a full-blown PC you can install non-gaming apps on. If Valve makes it a reasonable price, I could see it popping off, especially with the libraries of many consoles being nearly indistinguishable from that of the PC these days. A PC you play on your TV could easily become a viable alternative to buying a PlayStation or Xbox down the line.

When the new Steam Machine launches, Valve‚Äôs digital storefront will be adding a new indicator for games that perform optimally on the device, similar to the Steam Deck verification games go through now. IGN says that the Steam Machine is about as powerful as a last-generation PC, which means some modern games may have some performance struggles, but their experience with the device was an overall positive one.

‚ÄúValve says it intends for the Steam Machine to be able to play all current games at 4K with FSR upscaling, but there are going to be plenty of games ‚Äì especially ones running on Unreal Engine 5 ‚Äì where you‚Äôll have to lower settings to get it running at a smooth frame rate,‚Äù Jacqueline Thomas writes. ‚ÄúUltimately, I‚Äôll have to get it in the lab to benchmark it to see exactly what it‚Äôll be capable of, but I have little doubt this PC will be running most things ‚Äì it‚Äôs just that the quality settings are definitely going to vary.‚Äù

For now, the device is giving people a lot to speculate about, from the impact it could have on the console market to what kind of faceplates they can slap on the side of the thing to just how much it‚Äôs actually going to cost.
